data.title: 'This Is Not A Man,' 'Ramsey Show' Host Says After Wife Says Husband In Late 30s 'Refuses To Work' And Lives On $20K A Year From Parents
data.description:
Money problems are usually seen as numbers that don't add up. For Hannah, a mother in her early 40s from Salt Lake City, it has become a question of character.

She told "The Ramsey Show" hosts Rachel Cruz and John Delony that her husband, a welder in his late 30s, refuses to work and instead lives on $10,000 to $20,000 in annual gifts from his parents. 

As a result, Hannah covers the mortgage, utilities and most other costs while raising their toddler and her teenage daughter from a previous marriage.

Don't Miss:

  • Explore the Fire-Safe Energy Storage Company With $185M in Contracted Revenue
  • This AI Helps Fortune 1000 Brands Avoid Costly Ad Mistakes — See Why Investors Are Paying Attention

A One-Income Household By Default

"He’ll go back over there and he’ll hang out with friends and sometimes he picks up odd jobs, I guess," Hannah said, describing how her husband often drives about an hour to his hometown on the other four weekdays.

The money he receives each year around Christmas goes toward his personal expenses. After Hannah recently raised concerns, they began splitting the daycare bill.

Trending: Own the Characters, Not Just the Content: Inside a Fast-Growing Pre-IPO IP Company

She said resentment had been building as he refused to provide for his family and that the strain was affecting their relationship.

"Money is usually a revealing topic on how the marriage is doing," Cruz said.

A Marriage At A Crossroads

Delony said Hannah cannot make her husband change. Instead, he told her she faces two choices: leave the marriage or choose to stay and accept that he may not change.

"This is not a man," he said.

Delony said staying would mean solving the financial and childcare realities herself rather than waiting for him to change. Cruz asked whether divorce was truly an option for her or whether her past experience made her feel committed to staying.

Assets, Debt And Hard Questions

She worried that divorce could entitle him to part of her retirement savings or home equity gained during the marriage. Delony said that every state and every situation is different, and he urged Hannah to speak with an attorney before making assumptions about how assets would be divided.

"Every state’s different," he said. "Every situation’s different."

For someone like Hannah, the stakes go beyond monthly bills. Retirement savings and home equity can carry tax and legal consequences that are not immediately clear.

Some turn to fiduciary guidance in moments like this. Finance Advisors is a free platform that connects individuals planning for retirement with vetted professionals who specialize in tax-aware strategies.

The service does not sell products or manage investments. It matches users with advisors focused on after-tax income, withdrawal planning and long-term tax efficiency — helping them understand how major decisions could shape future income.

Image: Shutterstock

data.title: No, Bitcoin Isn't Artificially Being Kept Below $150,000 By Market Makers
data.description:
Bitwise Invest Chief Investment Officer Jeff Park argues Bitcoin (CRYPTO: BTC) is not being suppressed as claimed by some on social media. The issue, in fact, lies with ETF authorized participants.

The Regulatory Carve-Out

In a detailed explanation on X, Park points out that authorized participants operate under a special exemption that allows them to short ETF shares without borrowing costs, capital requirements, or deadlines to close positions. 

Any AP can create shares at will by virtue of their role in ETF creation and redemption.

This exemption isn’t unique to Jane Street.

For BlackRock’s (NASDAQ:IBIT) alone, nine firms have this power: Jane Street Capital, JPMorgan, Macquarie, Virtu Americas, Goldman Sachs, Citadel Securities, Citigroup, UBS, and ABN AMRO. All operate under the same rules.

The Broken Arbitrage

Normally, if IBIT trades below the value of its Bitcoin holdings, an arbitrage trader would buy IBIT shares, redeem them for Bitcoin, and pocket the difference. This buying pressure should close the gap.

But APs control the entire process, which changes the incentive structure. 

When APs short IBIT shares, they can hedge that short position with Bitcoin futures instead of buying actual Bitcoin spot. If they choose futures, no spot Bitcoin ever gets purchased.

This matters because the natural arbitrage that should push Bitcoin prices higher never happens. The buyer who should be closing the gap chose not to buy spot Bitcoin at all.

The In-Kind Problem

The SEC recently approved in-kind creation and redemption for Bitcoin ETFs. 

Under the old cash-only system, APs had to give cash to the fund, and the fund’s custodian would buy Bitcoin on the open market. That forced real spot buying.

The new system eliminates this requirement. APs can now deliver Bitcoin directly, sourced from over-the-counter desks at negotiated prices with minimal market impact. 

They can buy Bitcoin whenever and wherever they want, potentially after holding short positions for extended periods.

Park explains that the beginning of this process looks like normal market-making and the end looks like normal market-making. What happens in between is where the problems occur.

Image: Shutterstock

data.title: Intuitive Machines (LUNR) Stock Surges After Sharp Sell-Off: What's Going On?
data.description:
Intuitive Machines Inc (NASDAQ:LUNR) shares are trading higher Thursday, recovering some of the sharp losses seen in the previous session after the company unveiled sizable equity financing.

The move comes despite no fresh company-specific headlines, suggesting investors are reassessing Wednesday's sell-off and the implications of the deal for the space infrastructure firm.

Here’s what investors need to know.

  • Intuitive Machines stock is surging to new heights today. Why are LUNR shares rallying?

Capital Raise Funds Space Network Expansion

On Wednesday, LUNR sank after Intuitive Machines announced a $175 million strategic equity investment led by institutional investors, structured as an issuance of new Class A common stock.

The capital raise is intended to accelerate development of the company's Near Space Network Services and Lanteris satellite platforms, part of a broader effort to build a communications network connecting Earth orbit with the moon and, eventually, Mars.

Financing Fuels Growth, Adds Dilution Risk

While the financing supports Intuitive Machines' long-term growth ambitions and could help it secure more recurring government and commercial contracts, the offering introduces near-term dilution risk for existing shareholders and heightens the pressure on management to execute on complex lunar and deep-space projects.

Any delays, cost overruns or contract setbacks could weigh on future returns.

Late-2025 Breakout Lifts Moving Averages

Over the past year, Intuitive Machines has traded between a low of $6.48 and a high of $22.81, with shares spending much of 2025 oscillating around the $10–$13 area.

After moving mostly sideways through mid-2025, the stock broke out sharply late in the year, lifting the price and short-term moving averages above the longer-term 200-day trend line.

LUNR Earnings Due March

Intuitive Machines is slated to provide its next financial update on March 19.

  • EPS Estimate: Loss of 5 cents (Up from $-2.08)
  • Revenue Estimate: $53.34 million (Down from $54.66 million)

Buy Rating With Rising Targets

Analyst Consensus & Recent Actions: The stock carries a Buy Rating with an average price target of $18.00. Recent analyst moves include:

  • Keybanc: Overweight (Raises Target to $26.00) (Jan. 28)
  • Canaccord Genuity: Buy (Raises Target to $22.50) (Jan. 12)
  • Stifel: Downgraded to Hold (Raises Target to $20.00) (Jan. 9)

LUNR Shares Surge Thursday

LUNR Price Action: Intuitive Machines shares were up 10.76% at $17.61 at the time of publication on Thursday, according to Benzinga Pro data.

Image: Shutterstock
